Award.AwardTitle: Single Molecule Studies of Protein Folding

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to investigate the protein-folding problem using single molecule studies. Protein folding, the mechanism by which the amino acid sequence directs the energy landscape of a protein (the structures, energies, and rates of interconversion of all of the accessible conformations), remains a major challenge for modern molecular biology. Without a better understanding of how these features are encoded in a protein sequence, the expanding sequence databases continue to conceal the answers to many important questions. The project aims to develop methods for applying force or tension on a single protein molecule using tools such as an optical trap or magnetic tweezers and monitoring the conformation of the protein by following the distance between specific sites in the protein. The results will yield observables that can be used directly in theoretical studies of protein folding and the design of the experiments will be carried out in an iterative collaboration with theoreticians in the field. Mechanical stress plays a ubiquitous role in protein function and biology, and therefore, in addition to providing needed insight into the protein-folding problem this work will also provide much needed information about the mechanical stability of proteins.

In addition to its impact in protein folding and macromolecular biophysics, the research in this project requires training at the intersection of physics and biology: the work is a collaborative effort between a physics and a biochemistry lab. The work is not just interdisciplinary; it is actually interdependent, requiring state-of-the-art experiments in both physics and molecular biology. The work requires a combination of students and postdoctoral trainees with diverse backgrounds to work closely together. The project also involves the help of undergraduates, particularly those with a background in engineering and physics, giving them direct exposure to the biological sciences. In sum, this work offers a unique educational experience for the students and post-doctoral fellows involved in the project, and will help to train a new generation of scientists fluent in both the biological and quantitative sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The investigations funded by this focused on the understanding how proteins fold, i.e. the energetics and dynamics involved in forming their three-dimensional functional form.  By understanding what holds a protein together, how it assembles and how long it takes to assemble (the ‘energy landscape’), we will better understand the consequences when this goes wrong and design new proteins with specific and predictable properties. Most of the studies focused on the role force or mechanical stress plays in modulating the energy landscape. The investigations funded by this grant resulted 12 manuscripts.

In one focus area, we showed direct experimental evidence that proteins can access multiple folding and unfolding trajectories.  These exciting results provide important connections between theory and experiments in the field and reconcile a long-standing controversy. Importantly, we found that small changes in the environmental conditions or sequence of a protein can bias the flux through different transition states.  This has critical implications for protein folding in the cell (which occurs in a very unique environment) and the way we interpret the results of sequence variants and mutations (Jagannathan et al. PNAS 2012, Guinn et al.  Nature Communications 2015).

In another area, we discovered that the diffusion of an enzyme can increase during turnover. Using single molecule fluorescence correlation spectroscopy, we demonstrated that for three different enzymes catalyzing strongly exothermic reactions, the diffusion coefficients of the enzymes rise with increasing substrate concentration until all enzyme binding sites are saturated. This observation challenges the fundamental paradigm of enzymatic catalysis - that enzymes are unaffected by catalytic events converting substrate to product.  This novel perspective on how enzymes respond to the energy released during catalysis suggests a possible effect of the heat of reaction on the conformational ensemble of a protein (Reidel el al. Nature, 2015).

In a third area, we investigated the mechanical compliance of different states of proteins.  Previous mechanical studies had shown that native proteins are brittle: the distance to the transition state (Δx‡) is small. We found that partially folded molten globules can be very compliant. A large compliance has important implications for the behavior of proteins involved in mechanical force transduction: the application of small amounts of force (by motors such as an unfoldase or translocase) would have a bigger effect on the unfolding kinetics of a more compliant state (dlnk/dF = Δx‡). (Published in PNAS, Elms et al. 2012).

In our methodological advances, we built a hybrid magnetic tweezers/fluorescence microscope (TIRF) instrument, a single molecule ALEX confocal volume microscope, and evaluated the limitations of force feedback experiments in the optical trap. The hybrid instrument (mag-fleezers) allows us to follow force-dependent conformational changes at locations and distances not usually accessible in our optical trap approach. These protein-based experiments required us to develop a new methodology to incorporate both DNA handles and fluorophores in the protein - a combination of two bio-orthogonal chemistries: thiol chemistry and click chemistry. 

In our evaluation of experimental methods for equilibrium studies under conditions of constant-force or constant-trap position, we found that only constant trap position experiments yield parameters consistent with independently determined measurements. Our analysis showed that for molecules with fast kinetics, force fluctuations on a smaller time scale significantly alter the measured behavior. Simple modeling demonstrated that force-feedback studies result in an underestimate of the rate constants and an overestimate of the distances to the transition state. Thus, a constant trap position experiment with sampling frequency limited only by the response of the trapped bead is the best experiment for obtaining the highest quality data. (Elms et al. Biophysical Journal, Elms et al. 2012).

Finally, the PI, students and post-doctoral fellows involved in this work have developed several novel outeach and educational programs. Most notable are: 1) a new program “Thriving in Science: because just surviving is not enough” a professional development initiative intended to provide students and post-docs with the resources and support during their training period. The program is comprised of a mixture of peer support groups and monthly seminar style presentations.   2) “What you can be with a PhD” – a one-day symposium directed towards URM undergraduates to provide them with information about graduate school in STEM fields and the application process.  This symposium was held once in Berkeley, once in Texas, once in Atlanta, and once in Southern California, and 3) With a small supplement to this grant, Prof. Srebrenka Robic from Agnes Scott College (PUI) spent the summer in the lab setting up research projects to bring back to her home institution and provided career mentorship to Berkeley graduate students interested in teaching careers.  This experience has led to a new pilot project termed professional in residence.
